title: Quasiperiodic function
summary: In mathematics, a quasiperiodic function is a function that has a certain similarity to a periodic function.[1] A function f {\displaystyle f} is quasiperiodic with quasiperiod ω {\displaystyle \omega } if f ( z + ω ) = g ( z , f ( z ) ) {\displaystyle f(z+\omega )=g(z,f(z))} , where g {\displaystyle g} is a "simpler" function than f {\displaystyle f} . What it means to be "simpler" is vague.
